thread.title: Duke's task looks familiar, but Army could be different
thread.title_full: Duke's task looks familiar, but Army could be different

author: Bob Sutton Times-News bsutton@thetimesnews.com
title: Duke's task looks familiar, but Army could be different
text: Posted Oct. 10, 2015 at 1:26 AM Updated at 1:29 AM Duke might be well-schooled from a defensive standpoint in dealing with a triple-option offense. For the second time in three weeks, the Blue Devils will encounter that. This afternoon, it comes from Army’s version. “Seeing how they run a similar offense, we’re going to implement the same game plan,” Duke safety Jeremy Cash said. Cash excelled two weeks ago with a 12-tackle performance against Georgia Tech that resulted in weekly national recognition. “Going down and getting your nose in the heart of things,” Cash said of the approach. “When we play (against) a triple-option, I’m pretty much an outside linebacker.” Yet there is some caution in defending Army because not everything is the same. Army has more formations than Georgia Tech, based on what Duke players said they’ve learned. Blue Devils coach David Cutcliffe said Army’s unbalanced alignments can create havoc because defenses have to prove they can defend all of those. “It’s not going to be an easy game to just walk into,” Duke linebacker Dwayne Norman said. The familiarity could help the Blue Devils. But there’s another side to that as well because Army has had a chance to see how Duke nearly shutdown Georgia Tech’s rushing attack just two weeks ago. “That can work both ways,” Cutcliffe said. “It helps our players because they understand the challenge. … You’ve got to whip blocks and make tackles.” Duke players have been warned not to expect everything the same. They know Army’s discipline toward a task is one of the Cadets’ assets. “They’re a different opponent,” Norman said. “They’re not Georgia Tech.” Still, the Blue Devils anticipate a physical confrontation, perhaps much like they received last week with a run-oriented Boston College team. “Our team has to come off a physical game against Boston College and we have to get that mentality right back,” Cutcliffe said. Cutcliffe said the Blue Devils held some rugged practices during the week because there will be the ability to back off next week when the team doesn’t play. Duke has won its last six games in October. A victory today would give the Blue Devils a 5-1 record through six games in consecutive seasons, something that hasn’t happened for Duke’s football team since 1952-53. The Blue Devils said they’re not worried about historical footnotes at this stage because they don’t figure Army players are interested in that either. Page 2 of 2 - “They’re not going to care what our record is or what their record is,” Duke quarterback Thomas Sirk said. Duke at Army Records : Duke 4-1; Army 1-4) When : Noon today (CBS Sports Network) Where : Michie Stadium, West Point, N.Y. Series : Duke leads 11-10-1, though Army won the most-recent meeting in 2010. Extra points … This is Duke’s first road game since winning the opener at Tulane. … The Blue Devils have won 10 of their last 11 road games across parts of three seasons. … Duke is trying to move to 5-1 in consecutive seasons for the first time since 1952 and 1953. … The Blue Devils haven’t lost a game in October since falling to Florida State on Oct. 27, 2012. … Duke is coming off a 9-7 victory against Boston College, winning a game without a touchdown for the first time since a 3-0 decision against Wake Forest in 1978. … Duke kicker Ross Martin is 9-for-9 on field goals. He’s the only kicker in the country with at least nine attempts without a miss. … Duke’s most visible connection to Army is men’s basketball coach Mike Krzyzewski, who’s a 1969 graduate of West Point. By Bob Sutton
